Mathematical Foundations: Reliability Theory and the Inverse Design Problem

JoonHo Lee

2026-02-13

Source: vignettes/theory-reliability.Rmd
theory-reliability.Rmd
library(IRTsimrel)
set.seed(42)

Overview

This vignette provides the mathematical foundations for the reliability-targeted IRT simulation framework implemented in the IRTsimrel package. It develops the theory from first principles, connecting classical IRT measurement theory to the inverse calibration problem solved by the EQC and SAC algorithms.

Reading time: approximately 45â€“60 minutes.

Prerequisites: Familiarity with basic probability theory (expectation, variance, convergence), linear algebra, and the logistic function. Some exposure to item response theory is helpful but not strictly required.

Notation conventions: Random variables are denoted by Greek or capital Roman letters; vectors are boldfaced; hats denote estimators; bars and tildes denote specific reliability definitions (defined below).

Cross-references: For algorithm-specific details, see vignette("algorithm-eqc") and vignette("algorithm-sac"). For applied examples and workflows, see vignette("introduction").

The Two-Parameter Logistic IRT Model

We work within the two-parameter logistic (2PL) item response theory model. A test consists of II items administered to examinees drawn from a latent trait distribution GG.

Definition 1 (2PL Model). Let Î¸âˆ¼G\theta \sim G denote a latent ability parameter and let (Î²i,Î»i)(\beta_i, \lambda_i) denote the difficulty and discrimination parameters for item ii. The probability of a correct response is given by the item characteristic curve (ICC):

P(Xi=1âˆ£Î¸)=Ïˆ(Î»i(Î¸âˆ’Î²i)) P(X_i = 1 \mid \theta) = \psi\bigl(\lambda_i(\theta - \beta_i)\bigr) \tag{1}

where Ïˆ(z)=(1+eâˆ’z)âˆ’1\psi(z) = (1 + e^{-z})^{-1} is the standard logistic function.

The Rasch model is the special case where Î»i=1\lambda_i = 1 for all items ii.

Item and Test Information

The Fisher information provided by item ii at ability level Î¸\theta is:

Definition 2 (Item Information). Under the 2PL model,

ğ’¥i(Î¸)=Î»i2pi(Î¸)(1âˆ’pi(Î¸)) \mathcal{J}_i(\theta) = \lambda_i^2\, p_i(\theta)\, \bigl(1 - p_i(\theta)\bigr) \tag{2}

where pi(Î¸)=P(Xi=1âˆ£Î¸)p_i(\theta) = P(X_i = 1 \mid \theta) is given by Eq. (1).

Since p(1âˆ’p)p(1-p) achieves its maximum of 1/41/4 when p=1/2p = 1/2 (i.e., when Î¸=Î²i\theta = \beta_i), the maximum information from item ii is Î»i2/4\lambda_i^2 / 4.

Definition 3 (Test Information). The test information function is the sum of item information functions:

ğ’¥(Î¸)=âˆ‘i=1Iğ’¥i(Î¸)=âˆ‘i=1IÎ»i2pi(Î¸)(1âˆ’pi(Î¸)) \mathcal{J}(\theta) = \sum_{i=1}^{I} \mathcal{J}_i(\theta) = \sum_{i=1}^{I} \lambda_i^2\, p_i(\theta)\,\bigl(1 - p_i(\theta)\bigr) \tag{3}

Test information measures the precision of ability estimation at a given Î¸\theta. Higher information means smaller standard errors and more precise measurement.

The Conditional Standard Error

The asymptotic standard error of the maximum likelihood estimator Î¸Ì‚\hat{\theta} at Î¸\theta is:

SE(Î¸Ì‚âˆ£Î¸)=1ğ’¥(Î¸) \text{SE}(\hat{\theta} \mid \theta) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mathcal{J}(\theta)}} \tag{4}

This conditional error varies across the ability continuum, motivating the need for marginal (population-averaged) reliability measures.

Two Definitions of Marginal Reliability

Classical test theory defines reliability as the ratio of true-score variance to observed-score variance. In IRT, multiple marginalizations are possible, leading to distinct reliability definitions.

Let ÏƒÎ¸2=VarG(Î¸)\sigma^2_\theta = \text{Var}_G(\theta) denote the latent trait variance under the population distribution GG.

Average-Information Reliability (ÏÌƒ\tilde{\rho})

Definition 4 (Average-Information Reliability). The average-information marginal reliability is defined as:

ÏÌƒ(c)=ÏƒÎ¸2ğ’¥â€¾(c)ÏƒÎ¸2ğ’¥â€¾(c)+1 \tilde{\rho}(c) = \frac{\sigma^2_\theta\, \bar{\mathcal{J}}(c)} {\sigma^2_\theta\, \bar{\mathcal{J}}(c) + 1} \tag{5}

where ğ’¥â€¾(c)=ğ”¼G[ğ’¥(Î¸;c)]\bar{\mathcal{J}}(c) = \mathbb{E}_G[\mathcal{J}(\theta; c)] is the average test information under GG.

This definition first averages the test information, then converts to a reliability-like coefficient. It can be interpreted as the reliability one would obtain if the average measurement precision applied uniformly across all examinees.

In the package, this metric is selected with reliability_metric = "info" (or the synonym "tilde").

MSEM-Based Reliability (wâ€¾\bar{w})

Definition 5 (MSEM-Based Reliability). The marginal-standard-error-of- measurement (MSEM) based reliability is defined as:

wâ€¾(c)=ÏƒÎ¸2ÏƒÎ¸2+ğ”¼G[1/ğ’¥(Î¸;c)] \bar{w}(c) = \frac{\sigma^2_\theta} {\sigma^2_\theta + \mathbb{E}_G\bigl[1/\mathcal{J}(\theta; c)\bigr]} \tag{6}

This definition first takes the reciprocal of test information at each Î¸\theta (obtaining the conditional error variance), averages these error variances, and then forms the reliability ratio. It is the theoretically exact marginal reliability under the IRT model.

In the package, this metric is selected with reliability_metric = "msem" (or the synonym "bar").

Jensenâ€™s Inequality: ÏÌƒâ‰¥wâ€¾\tilde{\rho} \geq \bar{w}

The relationship between the two metrics is governed by Jensenâ€™s inequality.

Theorem 1 (Jensenâ€™s Inequality for Reliability Metrics). For any scaling factor c>0c > 0 and any latent distribution GG with ÏƒÎ¸2>0\sigma^2_\theta > 0,

ÏÌƒ(c)â‰¥wâ€¾(c) \tilde{\rho}(c) \geq \bar{w}(c) \tag{7}

with equality if and only if ğ’¥(Î¸;c)\mathcal{J}(\theta; c) is constant GG-almost surely.

Proof. The function f(x)=1/xf(x) = 1/x is strictly convex on (0,âˆ)(0, \infty). By Jensenâ€™s inequality applied to the random variable ğ’¥(Î¸;c)>0\mathcal{J}(\theta; c) > 0:

ğ”¼G[1ğ’¥(Î¸;c)]â‰¥1ğ”¼G[ğ’¥(Î¸;c)]=1ğ’¥â€¾(c) \mathbb{E}_G\!\left[\frac{1}{\mathcal{J}(\theta; c)}\right] \geq \frac{1}{\mathbb{E}_G\bigl[\mathcal{J}(\theta; c)\bigr]} = \frac{1}{\bar{\mathcal{J}}(c)} \tag{8}

Now compare the denominators of ÏÌƒ\tilde{\rho} and wâ€¾\bar{w}. The denominator of ÏÌƒ\tilde{\rho} in Eq. (5) can be rewritten as:

ÏƒÎ¸2ğ’¥â€¾(c)+1=ÏƒÎ¸2ğ’¥â€¾(c)+1 \sigma^2_\theta\, \bar{\mathcal{J}}(c) + 1 = \sigma^2_\theta\, \bar{\mathcal{J}}(c) + 1

while the denominator of wâ€¾\bar{w} in Eq. (6) is:

ÏƒÎ¸2+ğ”¼G[1ğ’¥(Î¸;c)] \sigma^2_\theta + \mathbb{E}_G\!\left[\frac{1}{\mathcal{J}(\theta; c)}\right]

From Eq. (8):

wâ€¾(c)=ÏƒÎ¸2ÏƒÎ¸2+ğ”¼[1/ğ’¥(Î¸;c)]â‰¤ÏƒÎ¸2ÏƒÎ¸2+1/ğ’¥â€¾(c)=ÏƒÎ¸2ğ’¥â€¾(c)ÏƒÎ¸2ğ’¥â€¾(c)+1=ÏÌƒ(c) \begin{aligned} \bar{w}(c) &= \frac{\sigma^2_\theta} {\sigma^2_\theta + \mathbb{E}[1/\mathcal{J}(\theta; c)]} \leq \frac{\sigma^2_\theta} {\sigma^2_\theta + 1/\bar{\mathcal{J}}(c)} \\[6pt] &= \frac{\sigma^2_\theta\, \bar{\mathcal{J}}(c)} {\sigma^2_\theta\, \bar{\mathcal{J}}(c) + 1} = \tilde{\rho}(c) \end{aligned}

where the inequality follows from ğ”¼[1/ğ’¥]â‰¥1/ğ’¥â€¾\mathbb{E}[1/\mathcal{J}] \geq 1/\bar{\mathcal{J}} (Jensen) and the monotone decreasing nature of xâ†¦ÏƒÎ¸2/(ÏƒÎ¸2+x)x \mapsto \sigma^2_\theta / (\sigma^2_\theta + x). Equality holds iff ğ’¥(Î¸;c)\mathcal{J}(\theta; c) is a.s. constant, i.e., when information does not vary across Î¸\theta. â–«\square

Numerical Verification of Jensenâ€™s Inequality

We can verify this inequality computationally using the packageâ€™s low-level reliability functions.

# Generate a latent trait sample and item parameters
theta <- sim_latentG(5000, shape = "normal")$theta
items <- sim_item_params(25, model = "rasch", source = "parametric")
beta  <- items$data$beta
lambda_base <- rep(1, 25)

# Compute both metrics across a range of c values
c_grid <- seq(0.3, 3.0, by = 0.1)
results <- data.frame(
  c = c_grid,
  rho_tilde = numeric(length(c_grid)),
  rho_bar   = numeric(length(c_grid)),
  gap       = numeric(length(c_grid))
)

for (j in seq_along(c_grid)) {
  both <- compute_rho_both(c_grid[j], theta, beta, lambda_base)
  results$rho_tilde[j] <- both$rho_tilde
  results$rho_bar[j]   <- both$rho_bar
  results$gap[j]       <- both$rho_tilde - both$rho_bar
}

# Verify: gap is always non-negative
cat(sprintf("Jensen's gap range: [%.6f, %.6f]\n",
            min(results$gap), max(results$gap)))
#> Jensen's gap range: [0.000209, 0.042706]
cat(sprintf("All gaps >= 0: %s\n", all(results$gap >= -1e-12)))
#> All gaps >= 0: TRUE
oldpar <- par(mfrow = c(1, 2), mar = c(4.5, 4.5, 3, 1))
on.exit(par(oldpar))

# Panel 1: Both metrics
plot(results$c, results$rho_tilde, type = "l", col = "steelblue", lwd = 2,
     xlab = "Scaling factor c", ylab = "Reliability",
     main = "Two Reliability Metrics", ylim = c(0, 1))
lines(results$c, results$rho_bar, col = "coral", lwd = 2, lty = 2)
legend("bottomright",
       legend = c(expression(tilde(rho) ~ "(info)"),
                  expression(bar(w) ~ "(msem)")),
       col = c("steelblue", "coral"), lty = c(1, 2), lwd = 2, cex = 0.9)

Figure 1: Jensenâ€™s gap between the two reliability metrics across scaling factors. 


# Panel 2: The gap
plot(results$c, results$gap, type = "l", col = "darkred", lwd = 2,
     xlab = "Scaling factor c", ylab = expression(tilde(rho) - bar(w)),
     main = "Jensen's Gap")
abline(h = 0, lty = 3, col = "gray50")

Figure 1: Jensenâ€™s gap between the two reliability metrics across scaling factors.

The gap is largest at intermediate cc values where information varies most across the ability continuum, and shrinks toward zero for very small cc (where both metrics approach zero) and very large cc (where information becomes uniformly high).

Scale Ordering Corollary

Corollary 1 (Scale Ordering). Let cÏÌƒ*c^*_{\tilde{\rho}} and cwâ€¾*c^*_{\bar{w}} denote the calibrated scaling factors for the same target Ï*\rho^* under the average-information and MSEM metrics, respectively. Then:

cwâ€¾*â‰¥cÏÌƒ* c^*_{\bar{w}} \geq c^*_{\tilde{\rho}} \tag{9}

Proof sketch. Since ÏÌƒ(c)â‰¥wâ€¾(c)\tilde{\rho}(c) \geq \bar{w}(c) for all cc, the MSEM metric reaches any given target level at a larger scaling factor than the information metric does. Formally, if ÏÌƒ(cÏÌƒ*)=Ï*\tilde{\rho}(c^*_{\tilde{\rho}}) = \rho^*, then wâ€¾(cÏÌƒ*)â‰¤ÏÌƒ(cÏÌƒ*)=Ï*\bar{w}(c^*_{\tilde{\rho}}) \leq \tilde{\rho}(c^*_{\tilde{\rho}}) = \rho^*, so wâ€¾\bar{w} must increase further (requiring larger cc) to reach Ï*\rho^*. â–«\square

This ordering is demonstrated numerically below.

# Calibrate with both metrics
eqc_info <- eqc_calibrate(
  target_rho = 0.80, n_items = 25, model = "rasch",
  item_source = "parametric", reliability_metric = "info",
  M = 5000L, seed = 42
)

eqc_msem <- eqc_calibrate(
  target_rho = 0.80, n_items = 25, model = "rasch",
  item_source = "parametric", reliability_metric = "msem",
  M = 5000L, seed = 42
)
#> Warning in eqc_calibrate(target_rho = 0.8, n_items = 25, model = "rasch", :
#> MSEM-based reliability (w-bar) may have a non-monotone objective for EQC (see
#> Lee, 2025, Section 4.3). Consider using 'info' (rho-tilde) for EQC, or use
#> sac_calibrate() which handles w-bar targeting correctly.

cat(sprintf("Target rho* = 0.80\n"))
#> Target rho* = 0.80
cat(sprintf("  c* (info metric): %.4f\n", eqc_info$c_star))
#>   c* (info metric): 0.8995
cat(sprintf("  c* (msem metric): %.4f\n", eqc_msem$c_star))
#>   c* (msem metric): 0.9232
cat(sprintf("  c*_msem >= c*_info: %s\n",
            eqc_msem$c_star >= eqc_info$c_star - 1e-6))
#>   c*_msem >= c*_info: TRUE

Global Discrimination Scaling

The central design variable in IRTsimrel is the global discrimination scaling factor c>0c > 0.

The Scaling Model

Definition 6 (Global Discrimination Scaling). Given baseline item discriminations ğ›Œ(0)=(Î»1(0),â€¦,Î»I(0))\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{(0)} = (\lambda_1^{(0)}, \ldots, \lambda_I^{(0)}) generated from an item parameter distribution HH, the scaled discriminations are:

Î»i(c)=câ‹…Î»i(0),i=1,â€¦,I \lambda_i(c) = c \cdot \lambda_i^{(0)}, \quad i = 1, \ldots, I \tag{10}

This scaling has several desirable properties:

  1. Separation of structure and informativeness: Changing cc modifies test information without altering the relative difficulty or discrimination structure among items.

  2. Dimensionality reduction: The multi-dimensional item parameter space is collapsed to a single scalar control variable cc.

  3. Smooth dependence: Both ÏÌƒ(c)\tilde{\rho}(c) and wâ€¾(c)\bar{w}(c) are smooth (infinitely differentiable) functions of cc for c>0c > 0.

Monotonicity of ÏÌƒ(c)\tilde{\rho}(c)

Proposition 1 (Monotonicity; cf.Â Proposition A.1, Lee 2025). The average-information reliability ÏÌƒ(c)\tilde{\rho}(c) is strictly monotonically increasing in cc for c>0c > 0.

Proof sketch. We show âˆ‚ÏÌƒ/âˆ‚c>0\partial \tilde{\rho} / \partial c > 0. From Eq. (5), by the chain rule and the fact that h(x)=x/(x+1)h(x) = x/(x+1) is strictly increasing for x>0x > 0, it suffices to show that ğ’¥â€¾(c)=ğ”¼G[ğ’¥(Î¸;c)]\bar{\mathcal{J}}(c) = \mathbb{E}_G[\mathcal{J}(\theta; c)] is strictly increasing in cc.

Differentiating the test information:

âˆ‚ğ’¥i(Î¸;c)âˆ‚c=2c(Î»i(0))2pi(1âˆ’pi)+c2(Î»i(0))2pi(1âˆ’pi)(1âˆ’2pi)â‹…Î»i(0)(Î¸âˆ’Î²i) \frac{\partial \mathcal{J}_i(\theta; c)}{\partial c} = 2c\, (\lambda_i^{(0)})^2\, p_i(1-p_i) + c^2\, (\lambda_i^{(0)})^2\, p_i(1-p_i)(1-2p_i) \cdot \lambda_i^{(0)}(\theta - \beta_i)

After taking the expectation over GG and summing over items, the dominant first-order term 2c(Î»i(0))2ğ”¼[pi(1âˆ’pi)]2c\,(\lambda_i^{(0)})^2\,\mathbb{E}[p_i(1-p_i)] is strictly positive for each item ii (since pi(1âˆ’pi)>0p_i(1-p_i) > 0 with positive probability), ensuring âˆ‚ğ’¥â€¾(c)/âˆ‚c>0\partial\bar{\mathcal{J}}(c)/\partial c > 0.

A more rigorous argument uses the representation ğ’¥â€¾(c)=c2âˆ‘i(Î»i(0))2ğ”¼[pi(Î¸;c)(1âˆ’pi(Î¸;c))]\bar{\mathcal{J}}(c) = c^2 \sum_i (\lambda_i^{(0)})^2 \mathbb{E}[p_i(\theta;c)(1-p_i(\theta;c))] and the fact that ğ”¼[pi(1âˆ’pi)]\mathbb{E}[p_i(1-p_i)] is bounded away from zero under regularity conditions. â–«\square

Existence and Uniqueness

Corollary 2 (Existence and Uniqueness; cf.Â Corollary 2.1, Lee 2025). Under mild regularity conditions, for any target Ï*âˆˆ(Ïmin,Ïmax)\rho^* \in (\rho_{\min}, \rho_{\max}) where

Ïmin=limcâ†’0+ÏÌƒ(c)=0andÏmax=limcâ†’âˆÏÌƒ(c)=1, \rho_{\min} = \lim_{c \to 0^+} \tilde{\rho}(c) = 0 \quad\text{and}\quad \rho_{\max} = \lim_{c \to \infty} \tilde{\rho}(c) = 1,

there exists a unique c*>0c^* > 0 satisfying ÏÌƒ(c*)=Ï*\tilde{\rho}(c^*) = \rho^*.

Proof. Since ÏÌƒ\tilde{\rho} is continuous (composition of continuous functions), strictly increasing (Proposition 1), and maps (0,âˆ)(0,\infty) onto (0,1)(0,1), existence and uniqueness follow from the intermediate value theorem and strict monotonicity. â–«\square

Non-Monotonicity of wâ€¾(c)\bar{w}(c)

Proposition 2 (Non-Monotonicity of MSEM; cf.Â Proposition A.5, Lee 2025). The MSEM-based reliability wâ€¾(c)\bar{w}(c) is not necessarily monotone in cc over the entire positive real line. In particular, for sufficiently large cc, wâ€¾(c)\bar{w}(c) can decrease.

Intuition. As câ†’âˆc \to \infty, for most Î¸\theta values far from any Î²i\beta_i, the item response probabilities pi(Î¸)p_i(\theta) approach 0 or 1, causing item information ğ’¥i(Î¸)=Î»i2pi(1âˆ’pi)â†’0\mathcal{J}_i(\theta) = \lambda_i^2 p_i(1-p_i) \to 0. Only Î¸\theta values very close to some Î²i\beta_i retain high information. The harmonic mean (used in wâ€¾\bar{w}) is dominated by the low-information regions, causing ğ”¼[1/ğ’¥]\mathbb{E}[1/\mathcal{J}] to grow and wâ€¾\bar{w} to decrease.

The arithmetic mean (used in ÏÌƒ\tilde{\rho}) is not as sensitive to these low- information tails, which is why ÏÌƒ\tilde{\rho} remains monotone.

This is why the c_bounds parameter matters in practice, especially when using the "msem" metric.

# Demonstrate non-monotonicity with a heavy-tailed distribution.
# Non-monotonicity is most prominent with heavy tails because extreme
# theta values far from any beta_i have near-zero information, and
# the harmonic mean (used in rho_bar) is dominated by these regions.
theta_nm <- sim_latentG(5000, shape = "heavy_tail", shape_params = list(df = 3))$theta

# Use 10 items with concentrated difficulties for a more visible effect
items_nm <- sim_item_params(10, model = "rasch", source = "parametric")
beta_nm  <- items_nm$data$beta
lambda_nm <- rep(1, 10)

c_wide <- seq(0.1, 15, length.out = 100)
rho_t <- rho_b <- numeric(length(c_wide))

for (j in seq_along(c_wide)) {
  both <- compute_rho_both(c_wide[j], theta_nm, beta_nm, lambda_nm)
  rho_t[j] <- both$rho_tilde
  rho_b[j] <- both$rho_bar
}

oldpar <- par(mar = c(4.5, 4.5, 3, 1))
on.exit(par(oldpar))

plot(c_wide, rho_t, type = "l", col = "steelblue", lwd = 2,
     xlab = "Scaling factor c", ylab = "Reliability",
     main = "Monotonicity Comparison (Heavy-Tailed Latent, df = 3)",
     ylim = c(0, 1))
lines(c_wide, rho_b, col = "coral", lwd = 2, lty = 2)

# Mark the maximum of rho_bar
idx_max <- which.max(rho_b)
points(c_wide[idx_max], rho_b[idx_max], pch = 19, col = "coral", cex = 1.5)

legend("right",
       legend = c(expression(tilde(rho) ~ "(always monotone)"),
                  expression(bar(w) ~ "(non-monotone at extreme c)")),
       col = c("steelblue", "coral"), lty = c(1, 2), lwd = 2, cex = 0.85)

Figure 2: Non-monotonicity of the MSEM metric at extreme scaling factors (heavy-tailed latent distribution, df = 3). 


cat(sprintf("rho_bar maximum at c = %.2f with value %.4f\n",
            c_wide[idx_max], rho_b[idx_max]))
#> rho_bar maximum at c = 0.25 with value 0.1285
cat(sprintf("rho_bar at c = %.1f: %.4f (decreasing)\n",
            max(c_wide), rho_b[length(c_wide)]))
#> rho_bar at c = 15.0: 0.0000 (decreasing)

Achievable Reliability Bounds

Not every target reliability is achievable for a given test configuration. The feasible range depends on the number of items, the item parameter distribution, and the latent trait distribution.

Upper Bound from the Logistic Kernel

Proposition 3 (Information Upper Bound). Under the 2PL model, the maximum item information is:

supÎ¸ğ’¥i(Î¸)=Î»i24 \sup_{\theta}\, \mathcal{J}_i(\theta) = \frac{\lambda_i^2}{4} \tag{11}

achieved when Î¸=Î²i\theta = \beta_i (i.e., pi=1/2p_i = 1/2). Therefore, the maximum test information is:

supÎ¸ğ’¥(Î¸;c)=c24âˆ‘i=1I(Î»i(0))2 \sup_{\theta}\, \mathcal{J}(\theta; c) = \frac{c^2}{4} \sum_{i=1}^{I} (\lambda_i^{(0)})^2 \tag{12}

For the Rasch model with Î»i(0)=1\lambda_i^{(0)} = 1, this simplifies to c2I/4c^2 I / 4.

Proof. The function p(1âˆ’p)p(1-p) on [0,1][0,1] has a unique maximum of 1/41/4 at p=1/2p = 1/2. Under the 2PL model, pi(Î¸)=1/2p_i(\theta) = 1/2 when Î¸=Î²i\theta = \beta_i. â–«\square

Feasibility Conditions

The average test information is bounded above by the maximum:

ğ’¥â€¾(c)=ğ”¼G[âˆ‘i=1IÎ»i(c)2pi(1âˆ’pi)]â‰¤c24âˆ‘i=1I(Î»i(0))2 \bar{\mathcal{J}}(c) = \mathbb{E}_G\!\left[\sum_{i=1}^{I} \lambda_i(c)^2\, p_i(1-p_i)\right] \leq \frac{c^2}{4} \sum_{i=1}^{I} (\lambda_i^{(0)})^2

Therefore the maximum achievable average-information reliability for a given cc is:

ÏÌƒmax(c)=ÏƒÎ¸2â‹…(c2/4)âˆ‘i(Î»i(0))2ÏƒÎ¸2â‹…(c2/4)âˆ‘i(Î»i(0))2+1 \tilde{\rho}_{\max}(c) = \frac{\sigma^2_\theta \cdot (c^2/4) \sum_i (\lambda_i^{(0)})^2} {\sigma^2_\theta \cdot (c^2/4) \sum_i (\lambda_i^{(0)})^2 + 1}

As câ†’âˆc \to \infty, this approaches 1, but in practice we work within câˆˆ[cmin,cmax]c \in [c_{\min}, c_{\max}] and the achievable range is finite.

Connection to check_feasibility()

The check_feasibility() function computes the achievable reliability range via Monte Carlo evaluation at the boundary scaling factors.

# Check feasibility for a 25-item Rasch test
feas <- check_feasibility(
  n_items = 25, model = "rasch",
  latent_shape = "normal",
  item_source = "parametric",
  c_bounds = c(0.1, 10),
  M = 5000L, seed = 42
)
#> 
#> =======================================================
#>   Feasibility Check: Achievable Reliability Range
#> =======================================================
#> 
#>   Number of items  : 25
#>   Model            : RASCH
#>   Latent shape     : normal
#>   Latent variance  : 1.0099
#>   c range          : [0.10, 10.00]
#>   Monte Carlo M    : 5000
#> 
#> Achievable Reliability Ranges:
#>   rho_tilde (info) : [0.0591, 0.9872]
#>   rho_bar   (msem) : [0.0002, 0.9146]
#> 
#> Note: rho_tilde >= rho_bar always (Jensen's inequality).
#>   Use rho_tilde range for EQC targets.
#>   Use rho_bar range for SAC targets.
# Test which targets are feasible
targets <- c(0.50, 0.70, 0.80, 0.90, 0.95)
for (rho in targets) {
  feasible_info <- rho >= feas$rho_range_info[1] & rho <= feas$rho_range_info[2]
  feasible_msem <- rho >= feas$rho_range_msem[1] & rho <= feas$rho_range_msem[2]
  cat(sprintf("  rho* = %.2f: info %s, msem %s\n",
              rho,
              ifelse(feasible_info, "YES", "NO "),
              ifelse(feasible_msem, "YES", "NO ")))
}
#>   rho* = 0.50: info YES, msem YES
#>   rho* = 0.70: info YES, msem YES
#>   rho* = 0.80: info YES, msem YES
#>   rho* = 0.90: info YES, msem YES
#>   rho* = 0.95: info YES, msem NO

Reliability Curves

The rho_curve() function visualizes how reliability changes with the scaling factor.

curve_data <- rho_curve(
  c_values = seq(0.1, 5, length.out = 60),
  n_items = 25, model = "rasch",
  latent_shape = "normal",
  item_source = "parametric",
  metric = "both",
  M = 5000L, seed = 42,
  plot = TRUE
)

Figure 3: Reliability curve for a 25-item Rasch test under a normal latent distribution.

EQC Theory: Deterministic Root-Finding

The Empirical Quadrature Calibration (EQC) algorithm solves the inverse reliability problem using deterministic root-finding on an empirical reliability function. Full algorithmic details are in vignette("algorithm-eqc"); here we state the main theoretical results.

Algorithm Sketch

EQC proceeds in three steps:

  1. Quadrature sampling: Draw {Î¸m}m=1Mâˆ¼G\{\theta_m\}_{m=1}^M \sim G and item parameters {(Î²i,Î»i(0))}i=1Iâˆ¼H\{(\beta_i, \lambda_i^{(0)})\}_{i=1}^I \sim H once.

  2. Empirical reliability function: For any c>0c > 0, define: ÏÌ‚M(c)=Ï(c;{Î¸m},ğ›ƒ,ğ›Œ(c)) \hat{\rho}_M(c) = \rho\bigl(c;\, \{\theta_m\},\, \boldsymbol{\beta},\, \boldsymbol{\lambda}(c)\bigr) \tag{13}

  3. Root-finding: Solve gM(c)=ÏÌ‚M(c)âˆ’Ï*=0g_M(c) = \hat{\rho}_M(c) - \rho^* = 0 using Brentâ€™s method on [cmin,cmax][c_{\min}, c_{\max}].

Consistency

Theorem 2 (Consistency of EQC; cf.Â Theorem A.1, Lee 2025). Let c*c^* be the true population solution and cÌ‚M*\hat{c}^*_M be the EQC solution with quadrature size MM. Then:

cÌ‚M*â†’a.s.c*as Mâ†’âˆ \hat{c}^*_M \xrightarrow{\text{a.s.}} c^* \quad \text{as } M \to \infty \tag{14}

Proof sketch. The empirical reliability ÏÌ‚M(c)\hat{\rho}_M(c) converges uniformly to Ï(c)\rho(c) over the compact interval [cmin,cmax][c_{\min}, c_{\max}] by the Uniform Law of Large Numbers (ULLN). Since Ï(c)\rho(c) is continuous and strictly monotone, and the root of the limit function is unique (Corollary 2), uniform convergence of the objective implies convergence of the root (by the continuous mapping theorem for M-estimators). â–«\square

Asymptotic Normality

Theorem 3 (Asymptotic Normality of EQC; cf.Â Theorem A.2, Lee 2025). Under regularity conditions, the EQC estimator satisfies:

M(cÌ‚M*âˆ’c*)â†’dN(0,Ïƒg2gâ€²(c*)2) \sqrt{M}\,\bigl(\hat{c}^*_M - c^*\bigr) \xrightarrow{d} N\!\left(0,\, \frac{\sigma^2_g}{g'(c^*)^2}\right) \tag{15}

where g(c)=Ï(c)âˆ’Ï*g(c) = \rho(c) - \rho^*, gâ€²(c*)g'(c^*) is the derivative of the reliability function at the solution, and Ïƒg2\sigma^2_g is the asymptotic variance of the empirical gradient.

Proof sketch. Apply the delta method to the implicit function cÌ‚M*=gMâˆ’1(Ï*)\hat{c}^*_M = g^{-1}_M(\rho^*). The Central Limit Theorem gives M(ÏÌ‚M(c)âˆ’Ï(c))â†’dN(0,Ïƒg2)\sqrt{M}(\hat{\rho}_M(c) - \rho(c)) \to_d N(0, \sigma^2_g), and the implicit function theorem (applicable since gâ€²(c*)â‰ 0g'(c^*) \neq 0 by strict monotonicity) yields the result. â–«\square

Monte Carlo Error Bounds

The practical implication of Theorem 3 is:

|cÌ‚M*âˆ’c*|=Op(1M) |\hat{c}^*_M - c^*| = O_p\!\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}\right) \tag{16}

The reliability estimate itself has error:

|ÏÌ‚M(c)âˆ’Ï(c)|=Op(1M) |\hat{\rho}_M(c) - \rho(c)| = O_p\!\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}\right)

Quadrature size MM Approx. MC std. error
1,000 ~0.03
5,000 ~0.014
10,000 ~0.01
50,000 ~0.004
100,000 ~0.003

SAC Theory: Stochastic Approximation

The Stochastic Approximation Calibration (SAC) algorithm provides an independent solution path using the Robbins-Monro framework. Full algorithmic details are in vignette("algorithm-sac").

The Stochastic Root-Finding Problem

SAC targets the equation:

g(c)=ğ”¼[ÏÌ‚(c)]âˆ’Ï*=0 g(c) = \mathbb{E}\!\left[\hat{\rho}(c)\right] - \rho^* = 0 \tag{17}

At each iteration nn, only a noisy observation ÏÌ‚n(cn)=Ï*+g(cn)+Îµn\hat{\rho}_n(c_n) = \rho^* + g(c_n) + \varepsilon_n is available, where Îµn\varepsilon_n is zero-mean Monte Carlo noise.

Robbins-Monro Update

The iterative update rule is:

cn+1=Î [cL,cU][cnâˆ’an(ÏÌ‚n(cn)âˆ’Ï*)] c_{n+1} = \Pi_{[c_L, c_U]}\!\left[c_n - a_n\,\bigl(\hat{\rho}_n(c_n) - \rho^*\bigr)\right] \tag{18}

where Î [cL,cU]\Pi_{[c_L, c_U]} denotes projection onto the constraint set and the step size sequence satisfies the Robbins-Monro conditions:

an=a(n+A)Î³,âˆ‘n=1âˆan=âˆ,âˆ‘n=1âˆan2<âˆ a_n = \frac{a}{(n + A)^\gamma}, \quad \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n = \infty, \quad \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n^2 < \infty \tag{19}

These conditions are satisfied when Î³âˆˆ(1/2,1]\gamma \in (1/2, 1].

Polyak-Ruppert Averaging

Rather than using the final iterate cNc_N, SAC computes the Polyak-Ruppert average over post-burn-in iterates:

câ€¾N=1Nâˆ’Bâˆ‘n=B+1Ncn \bar{c}_N = \frac{1}{N - B} \sum_{n=B+1}^{N} c_n \tag{20}

where BB is the burn-in period. This averaging achieves the optimal convergence rate.

Convergence

Theorem 4 (SAC Convergence; cf.Â Theorem A.3, Lee 2025). Under the Robbins-Monro conditions (Eq. 19) and standard regularity assumptions (boundedness of gg, Lipschitz continuity, noise variance bounded), the SAC iterates converge almost surely:

cnâ†’a.s.c*as nâ†’âˆ c_n \xrightarrow{\text{a.s.}} c^* \quad \text{as } n \to \infty \tag{21}

Furthermore, the Polyak-Ruppert average satisfies:

Nâˆ’B(câ€¾Nâˆ’c*)â†’dN(0,ÏƒÎµ2gâ€²(c*)2) \sqrt{N - B}\,(\bar{c}_N - c^*) \xrightarrow{d} N\!\left(0,\, \frac{\sigma^2_\varepsilon}{g'(c^*)^2}\right) \tag{22}

achieving the optimal O(nâˆ’1/2)O(n^{-1/2}) rate, compared to O(nâˆ’Î³)O(n^{-\gamma}) for the final iterate.

Proof sketch. Almost sure convergence follows from the classical Robbins-Monro theorem (Robbins and Monro, 1951), extended to the projected case by Kushner and Yin (2003). The key conditions are: (i) g(c*)=0g(c^*) = 0, (ii) gâ€²(c*)>0g'(c^*) > 0 (strict monotonicity from Proposition 1), (iii) the step size conditions in Eq. (19), and (iv) bounded conditional variance Var(Îµnâˆ£cn)â‰¤ÏƒÎµ2\text{Var}(\varepsilon_n \mid c_n) \leq \sigma^2_\varepsilon. Asymptotic normality of the Polyak-Ruppert average follows from Polyak and Juditsky (1992). â–«\square

Numerical Demonstrations

Verifying Theoretical Predictions

We use the low-level reliability functions to verify key theoretical properties.

# Common setup for demonstrations
M_demo <- 5000L
theta_demo <- sim_latentG(M_demo, shape = "normal")$theta
items_demo <- sim_item_params(30, model = "rasch", source = "parametric")
beta_demo  <- items_demo$data$beta
lambda_demo <- rep(1, 30)
theta_var_demo <- var(theta_demo)

Verification 1: Reliability increases with c (info metric) 

c_test <- c(0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3.0)
rho_info <- sapply(c_test, function(cc) {
  compute_rho_tilde(cc, theta_demo, beta_demo, lambda_demo,
                    theta_var = theta_var_demo)
})

cat("Monotonicity check (info metric):\n")
#> Monotonicity check (info metric):
for (j in seq_along(c_test)) {
  cat(sprintf("  c = %.1f: rho_tilde = %.4f", c_test[j], rho_info[j]))
  if (j > 1) {
    cat(sprintf("  (diff = %+.4f)", rho_info[j] - rho_info[j-1]))
  }
  cat("\n")
}
#>   c = 0.5: rho_tilde = 0.6286
#>   c = 1.0: rho_tilde = 0.8456  (diff = +0.2171)
#>   c = 1.5: rho_tilde = 0.9082  (diff = +0.0626)
#>   c = 2.0: rho_tilde = 0.9351  (diff = +0.0269)
#>   c = 2.5: rho_tilde = 0.9498  (diff = +0.0147)
#>   c = 3.0: rho_tilde = 0.9590  (diff = +0.0092)
cat(sprintf("All differences positive: %s\n", all(diff(rho_info) > 0)))
#> All differences positive: TRUE

Verification 2: Jensenâ€™s gap depends on information heterogeneity

Non-standard latent distributions produce larger Jensenâ€™s gaps because information varies more across the ability continuum.

shapes <- c("normal", "bimodal", "heavy_tail", "skew_pos")
shape_pars <- list(
  normal     = list(),
  bimodal    = list(delta = 0.9),
  heavy_tail = list(df = 5),
  skew_pos   = list(k = 4)
)

c_val <- 1.5
cat(sprintf("Jensen's gap at c = %.1f for different latent shapes:\n", c_val))
#> Jensen's gap at c = 1.5 for different latent shapes:

for (sh in shapes) {
  theta_sh <- sim_latentG(M_demo, shape = sh, shape_params = shape_pars[[sh]])$theta
  both_sh <- compute_rho_both(c_val, theta_sh, beta_demo, lambda_demo)
  gap <- both_sh$rho_tilde - both_sh$rho_bar
  cat(sprintf("  %-12s: rho_tilde = %.4f, rho_bar = %.4f, gap = %.4f\n",
              sh, both_sh$rho_tilde, both_sh$rho_bar, gap))
}
#>   normal      : rho_tilde = 0.9113, rho_bar = 0.9011, gap = 0.0102
#>   bimodal     : rho_tilde = 0.9070, rho_bar = 0.9040, gap = 0.0031
#>   heavy_tail  : rho_tilde = 0.9117, rho_bar = 0.8293, gap = 0.0824
#>   skew_pos    : rho_tilde = 0.9122, rho_bar = 0.8862, gap = 0.0260

Verification 3: APC initialization quality

The Analytic Pre-Calibration (APC) formula provides a closed-form starting point. We compare it against the EQC solution.

targets <- c(0.60, 0.70, 0.80, 0.85, 0.90)
cat("APC initialization vs EQC solution (Rasch, 25 items, normal):\n")
#> APC initialization vs EQC solution (Rasch, 25 items, normal):
cat(sprintf("  %-10s %-10s %-10s %-10s\n", "Target", "c_APC", "c_EQC", "Ratio"))
#>   Target     c_APC      c_EQC      Ratio

for (rho_t in targets) {
  c_apc <- compute_apc_init(target_rho = rho_t, n_items = 25)
  eqc_t <- eqc_calibrate(
    target_rho = rho_t, n_items = 25, model = "rasch",
    item_source = "parametric", M = 5000L, seed = 42, verbose = FALSE
  )
  cat(sprintf("  %-10.2f %-10.4f %-10.4f %-10.2f\n",
              rho_t, c_apc, eqc_t$c_star, c_apc / eqc_t$c_star))
}
#>   0.60       0.8129     0.5118     1.59      
#>   0.70       1.0138     0.6548     1.55      
#>   0.80       1.3274     0.8995     1.48      
#>   0.85       1.5799     1.1199     1.41      
#>   0.90       1.9911     1.5328     1.30

Verification 4: Effect of test length on achievable reliability 

n_items_grid <- c(10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 40, 50)
c_fixed <- 1.0

cat(sprintf("Reliability at c = %.1f for different test lengths:\n", c_fixed))
#> Reliability at c = 1.0 for different test lengths:
for (ni in n_items_grid) {
  items_ni <- sim_item_params(ni, model = "rasch", source = "parametric")
  beta_ni  <- items_ni$data$beta
  lambda_ni <- rep(1, ni)

  both_ni <- compute_rho_both(c_fixed, theta_demo, beta_ni, lambda_ni,
                               theta_var = theta_var_demo)
  cat(sprintf("  I = %2d: rho_tilde = %.4f, rho_bar = %.4f\n",
              ni, both_ni$rho_tilde, both_ni$rho_bar))
}
#>   I = 10: rho_tilde = 0.6514, rho_bar = 0.6406
#>   I = 15: rho_tilde = 0.7213, rho_bar = 0.7158
#>   I = 20: rho_tilde = 0.7797, rho_bar = 0.7738
#>   I = 25: rho_tilde = 0.8165, rho_bar = 0.8112
#>   I = 30: rho_tilde = 0.8510, rho_bar = 0.8442
#>   I = 40: rho_tilde = 0.8768, rho_bar = 0.8730
#>   I = 50: rho_tilde = 0.8995, rho_bar = 0.8961

EQC vs SAC Agreement 

eqc_demo <- eqc_calibrate(
  target_rho = 0.80, n_items = 25, model = "rasch",
  item_source = "parametric", reliability_metric = "info",
  M = 5000L, seed = 42, verbose = FALSE
)

sac_demo <- sac_calibrate(
  target_rho = 0.80, n_items = 25, model = "rasch",
  item_source = "parametric", reliability_metric = "info",
  c_init = eqc_demo, n_iter = 300L, M_per_iter = 1000L,
  seed = 42, verbose = FALSE
)

cat("EQC vs SAC comparison (target = 0.80, info metric):\n")
#> EQC vs SAC comparison (target = 0.80, info metric):
cat(sprintf("  EQC c*:        %.4f\n", eqc_demo$c_star))
#>   EQC c*:        0.8995
cat(sprintf("  SAC c*:        %.4f\n", sac_demo$c_star))
#>   SAC c*:        0.9122
cat(sprintf("  Abs diff:      %.4f\n", abs(eqc_demo$c_star - sac_demo$c_star)))
#>   Abs diff:      0.0127
cat(sprintf("  Pct diff:      %.2f%%\n",
            100 * abs(eqc_demo$c_star - sac_demo$c_star) / eqc_demo$c_star))
#>   Pct diff:      1.41%

Verification 5: Reliability function under the 2PL model

The 2PL model introduces additional variability through heterogeneous baseline discriminations.

items_2pl <- sim_item_params(25, model = "2pl", source = "parametric")
beta_2pl  <- items_2pl$data$beta
lambda_2pl <- if ("lambda_unscaled" %in% names(items_2pl$data)) {
  items_2pl$data$lambda_unscaled
} else {
  items_2pl$data$lambda
}

cat("2PL baseline discriminations:\n")
#> 2PL baseline discriminations:
cat(sprintf("  Range: [%.3f, %.3f]\n", min(lambda_2pl), max(lambda_2pl)))
#>   Range: [0.411, 2.144]
cat(sprintf("  Mean:  %.3f\n", mean(lambda_2pl)))
#>   Mean:  1.165
cat(sprintf("  SD:    %.3f\n", sd(lambda_2pl)))
#>   SD:    0.383

# Compare Rasch and 2PL reliability at same c
c_compare <- 1.0
both_rasch <- compute_rho_both(c_compare, theta_demo,
                                beta_demo[1:25], rep(1, 25),
                                theta_var = theta_var_demo)
both_2pl <- compute_rho_both(c_compare, theta_demo,
                              beta_2pl, lambda_2pl,
                              theta_var = theta_var_demo)

cat(sprintf("\nReliability comparison at c = %.1f:\n", c_compare))
#> 
#> Reliability comparison at c = 1.0:
cat(sprintf("  Rasch: rho_tilde = %.4f, rho_bar = %.4f, gap = %.4f\n",
            both_rasch$rho_tilde, both_rasch$rho_bar,
            both_rasch$rho_tilde - both_rasch$rho_bar))
#>   Rasch: rho_tilde = 0.8213, rho_bar = 0.8152, gap = 0.0062
cat(sprintf("  2PL:   rho_tilde = %.4f, rho_bar = %.4f, gap = %.4f\n",
            both_2pl$rho_tilde, both_2pl$rho_bar,
            both_2pl$rho_tilde - both_2pl$rho_bar))
#>   2PL:   rho_tilde = 0.8556, rho_bar = 0.8444, gap = 0.0112

Heterogeneous discriminations typically produce a larger Jensenâ€™s gap because the test information varies more across the ability continuum.

The Inverse Design Problem

The theoretical framework above describes the forward problem: given a scaling factor cc, compute the reliability Ï(c)\rho(c). The central contribution of the IRTsimrel package is solving the inverse problem.

Problem Statement

Definition 7 (Inverse Reliability Problem). Given a target marginal reliability Ï*âˆˆ(0,1)\rho^* \in (0, 1), find a global discrimination scaling factor c*>0c^* > 0 such that:

Ï(c*)=Ï* \rho(c^*) = \rho^* \tag{23}

where Ï\rho denotes either ÏÌƒ\tilde{\rho} (average-information) or wâ€¾\bar{w} (MSEM-based), depending on the chosen metric.

Why the Inverse Problem is Difficult

Several factors make this inverse problem non-trivial:

  1. No closed-form solution: The reliability function involves a logistic nonlinearity inside an expectation over GG. Even in the simplest Rasch case with normal GG, no analytic inversion is possible.

  2. Distribution dependence: The mapping câ†¦Ï(c)c \mapsto \rho(c) depends on the full distributions GG (latent traits) and HH (item parameters), not just their moments.

  3. Metric ambiguity: The two reliability definitions yield different c*c^* values for the same target (Corollary 1).

  4. Practical constraints: The scaling factor must lie within bounds that produce realistic item parameters.

The APC Approximation

The Analytic Pre-Calibration (APC) formula provides a rough initial estimate under Gaussian Rasch assumptions. With Î¸âˆ¼N(0,1)\theta \sim N(0,1) and Î²âˆ¼N(0,ÏƒÎ²2)\beta \sim N(0, \sigma^2_\beta), the expected item information involves the logistic-normal convolution constant:

Îº(Ïƒ2)=âˆ«âˆ’âˆâˆez(1+ez)2Ï•(z;0,Ïƒ2)dzâ‰ˆ0.251+Ïƒ2Ï€2/3 \kappa(\sigma^2) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{e^z}{(1+e^z)^2}\, \phi(z; 0, \sigma^2)\, dz \approx \frac{0.25}{\sqrt{1 + \sigma^2 \pi^2 / 3}} \tag{24}

where Ïƒ2=1+ÏƒÎ²2\sigma^2 = 1 + \sigma^2_\beta. The APC initial value is:

cAPC=Ï*Iâ‹…Îºâ‹…(1âˆ’Ï*) c_{\text{APC}} = \sqrt{\frac{\rho^*}{I \cdot \kappa \cdot (1 - \rho^*)}} \tag{25}

This approximation is typically within a factor of 2 of the true c*c^* and serves as a starting point for the stochastic approximation algorithm (SAC).

Complete Notation Table

The following table summarizes all mathematical notation used in the package and its documentation.

Summary of Theoretical Results

Result Statement Implication
Theorem 1 ÏÌƒ(c)â‰¥wâ€¾(c)\tilde{\rho}(c) \geq \bar{w}(c) (Jensen) Info metric always yields higher reliability values
Corollary 1 cwâ€¾*â‰¥cÏÌƒ*c^*_{\bar{w}} \geq c^*_{\tilde{\rho}} MSEM metric requires larger scaling factor
Proposition 1 ÏÌƒ(c)\tilde{\rho}(c) is strictly increasing Existence and uniqueness for info metric
Corollary 2 Unique c*c^* exists for Ï*âˆˆ(0,1)\rho^* \in (0,1) EQC root-finding is well-defined
Proposition 2 wâ€¾(c)\bar{w}(c) is not always monotone c_bounds critical for MSEM metric
Proposition 3 maxğ’¥i=Î»i2/4\max \mathcal{J}_i = \lambda_i^2/4 Upper bound on achievable reliability
Theorem 2 EQC consistent (cÌ‚M*â†’c*\hat{c}^*_M \to c^* a.s.) Arbitrarily precise via larger MM
Theorem 3 EQC asymptotically normal (M\sqrt{M} rate) Quantifiable uncertainty
Theorem 4 SAC converges a.s., optimal rate with PR avg Independent validation pathway
